elements.content: Pd(II)−N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) metallacrown ether complexes have been synthesized for the first time. Reaction of bis(imidazolium) salts with a long polyether chain with Ag2O afforded silver−NHC complexes [Ag2(L)Cl2] 5, which reacted as carbene transfer reagents with palladium salts to give Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ether complexes 6a,b. The Ag(I)−NHC complex 5b possesses a one-dimensional chain configuration by each Ag(I) center coordinated to one carbene and two bridging chlorides. Each of Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ether complexes 6a,b contains a 25-membered macrocyclic NHC metallacrown ether formed by a bidentate chelate bis(carbene) ligand with a long flexible linkage and a Pd(II). The coordination geometry on the Pd(II) is approximately square planar. Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ether complexes 6a and 6b have been shown to be highly effective in the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection.
elements.clean_text: Pd(II)-N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) metallacrown ether complexes have been synthesized for the first time. The Ag(I)-NHC complex 5b possesses a one-dimensional chain configuration by each Ag(I) center coordinated to one carbene and two bridging chlorides. Each of Pd(II)-NHC metallacrown ether complexes 6a,b contains a 25-membered macrocyclic NHC metallacrown ether formed by a bidentate chelate bis(carbene) ligand with a long flexible linkage and a Pd(II). The coordination geometry on the Pd(II) is approximately square planar. Pd(II)-NHC metallacrown ether complexes 6a and 6b have been shown to be highly effective in the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection.

elements.content: A new type of Pd−NHC complexes, Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ethers, has been synthesized. These Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ethers are highly active catalysts in the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection with TON up to 99 000.

These Pd(II)-NHC metallacrown ethers are highly active catalysts in the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection with TON up to 99000.

elements.content: Phosphine ligands are widely used in transition metal chemistry. Phosphine ligands containing a secondary site for coordination that can play an important role in catalytic processes are especially of interest. Crown ether phosphines, which combine the two features of transition metal complex and crown ether in the same molecule, constitute a bifunctionalization that not only permits investigations of interactions between ionic compounds insoluble in organic solvents and hydrophobic metal complexes but also accelerates metal-catalyzed reactions between organic substrates and the ionic compounds. A number of hybrid crown ether phosphine ligands, some of which are active catalysts for organic transformations, have been reported in the literature since the first report by Shaw et al. in 1978. A related class of compounds to crown ether phosphines are the metallacrown ethers formed by chelation of α,ω-bis(phosphorus donor)polyether ligands to transition metals. Studies on these metallacrown ethers have shown that they exhibit a variety of phosphine coordination geometries, and they are capable of coordinating to alkali metal cations. Such hard−soft bimetallic complexes could be used to activate a variety of bifunctional ligands, such as carbonyls that can coordinate to both metal centers. This property could be quite useful in the design of catalysts for reactions involving such ligands. To date, however, there is little information available concerning the application of phosphine metallacrown ethers as catalysts despite the potential already visible in the published work.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Phosphine ligands are widely used in transition metal chemistry. Phosphine ligands containing a secondary site for coordination that can play an important role in catalytic processes are especially of interest. Crown ether phosphines, which combine the two features of transition metal complex and crown ether in the same molecule, constitute a bifunctionalization that not only permits investigations of interactions between ionic compounds insoluble in organic solvents and hydrophobic metal complexes but also accelerates metal-catalyzed reactions between organic substrates and the ionic compounds. A number of hybrid crown ether phosphine ligands, some of which are active catalysts for organic transformations, have been reported in the literature since the first report by Shaw et al. in 1978. A related class of compounds to crown ether phosphines are the metallacrown ethers formed by chelation of α,ω-bis(phosphorus donor)polyether ligands to transition metals. Studies on these metallacrown ethers have shown that they exhibit a variety of phosphine coordination geometries, and they are capable of coordinating to alkali metal cations. Such hard-soft bimetallic complexes could be used to activate a variety of bifunctional ligands, such as carbonyls that can coordinate to both metal centers. This property could be quite useful in the design of catalysts for reactions involving such ligands. To date, however, there is little information available concerning the application of phosphine metallacrown ethers as catalysts despite the potential already visible in the published work.

elements.content: N-Heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands have been found to be interesting substitutes for phosphine ligands and employed with considerable success in coordination chemistry and various catalytic transformations. Substitution of phosphine donors with NHCs has led to several examples of NHC metallacrown ether. Cavell et al. prepared an oxoether-bridged bis(imidazolium) ligand and its Ag-containing dimetallacrown rings of smaller size. Rogers et al. reported a mercury(II) carbene complex containing a three-ether spacer, which revealed the possibility of a carbene extraction mechanism. Zhang et al. described bidentate NHC-bridged dinuclear Ag(I), Au(I), and Cu(I) cationic metallacrown ethers. These publications were mainly focused on the synthesis and characterization, no application of NHC metallacrown ethers as catalysts for organic transformations has been documented.
elements.clean_text: N-Heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands have been found to be interesting substitutes for phosphine ligands and employed with considerable success in coordination chemistry and various catalytic transformations. Cavell et al. prepared an oxoether-bridged bis(imidazolium) ligand and its Ag-containing dimetallacrown rings of smaller size. Rogers et al. reported a mercury(II) carbene complex containing a three-ether spacer, which revealed the possibility of a carbene extraction mechanism. Zhang et al. described bidentate NHC-bridged dinuclear Ag(I), Au(I), and Cu(I) cationic metallacrown ethers. These publications were mainly focused on the synthesis and characterization, no application of NHC metallacrown ethers as catalysts for organic transformations has been documented.

elements.content: Pd−NHC complexes are known to catalyze a wide range of useful cross-coupling reactions. However, we were surprised that there has been no report on Pd−NHC metallacrown ethers described to date. Guided by the explorations of crown ether phosphines and metallacrown ethers formed by chelation of α,ω-bis(phosphorus donor)polyether ligands to transition metals, we envisioned if Pd−NHC metallacrown ether could be synthesized, it would be a new type of Pd−NHC complexes that may display useful properties for catalytic applications. Herein we wish to present the first synthesis and characterization of Pd−NHC metallacrown ethers and their application as catalysts for the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions in water.

Herein we wish to present the first synthesis and characterization of Pd-NHC metallacrown ethers and their application as catalysts for the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions in water.

elements.content: The synthetic routes to imidazolium salt precursors 4 used to prepare the Pd−NHC metallacrown ethers are shown in Scheme . Compound 1 was prepared by the classical method from catechol and 1,2-bis(2-chloroethoxy)ethane. Reaction of 1 with 2-chlorethanol using the same procedure gave compound 2. Chlorination of 2 with thionyl chloride was optimized to give 3 in good isolated yield. Compound 3 was subsequently treated with substituted imidazoles to give the corresponding bis(imidazolium) salts 4. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopic data for 4 obtained in CDCl3 showed spectra consistent with Cs symmetry, and in the 1H NMR spectra, characteristic signals of the imidazolium salt NC(H)N protons were observed at 10.35 and 9.67 ppm. These values fall in the range observed for related imidazolium salts.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Ligand and Metal Complex Synthesis

The synthetic routes to imidazolium salt precursors 4 used to prepare the Pd-NHC metallacrown ethers are shown in Scheme . Compound 1 was prepared by the classical method from catechol and 1,2-bis(2-chloroethoxy)ethane. Reaction of 1 with 2-chlorethanol using the same procedure gave compound 2. Chlorination of 2 with thionyl chloride was optimized to give 3 in good isolated yield. Compound 3 was subsequently treated with substituted imidazoles to give the corresponding bis(imidazolium) salts 4. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopic data for 4 obtained in CDCl3 showed spectra consistent with Cs  symmetry, and in the 1H NMR spectra, characteristic signals of the imidazolium salt NC(H)N protons were observed at 10.35 and 9.67 ppm. These values fall in the range observed for related imidazolium salts.

elements.content: Transmetalation has proved to be a promising procedure to obtain metal−NHC complexes, which typically involves treatment of the imidazolium salt with silver oxide to form the Ag−NHC complex, followed by transmetalation to a species such as [PdCl2(MeCN)2] to give the metal−carbene complexes. Mixing imidazolium salts 4 with Ag2O in CH2Cl2 at room temperature for 2 h afforded the silver−NHC complexes [Ag2(L)Cl2] 5 (Scheme ). The Ag−NHC coordination of 5b was established by the absence of the 1H resonance for the 2H-imidazolium proton. 13C NMR shift was not observed most likely because of the fluxional behavior of the NHC complexes in solution. Although it was clearly observed that the reaction of imidazolium salt 4a with silver oxide occurred when the dark reaction mixture turned pale, the corresponding pure Ag−NHC complex 5a was not isolated.

Mixing imidazolium salts 4 with Ag2O in CH2Cl2 at room temperature for 2 h afforded the silver-NHC complexes [Ag2(L)Cl2] 5 (Scheme ). Although it was clearly observed that the reaction of imidazolium salt 4a with silver oxide occurred when the dark reaction mixture turned pale, the corresponding pure Ag-NHC complex 5a was not isolated.

elements.content: The colorless, air-stable single crystals of 5b suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O into its MeCN solution. X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the bidentate NHC ligand arranges in an antiparallel fashion and coordinates to two different Ag(I) ions (Figure ). Each Ag(I) center is coordinated to a carbene and two bridging chloride ligands to adopt a distorted trigonal planar geometry with the sums of angles at the metal center being 359.74°. Each Ag(I) also possesses a bridging chloride, which coordinates to another through the inversion-related Ag(I) center of the next molecule and hence links up the [Ag2LCl2] units into an extended one-dimensional chain polymer. The Ag1−C13 and Ag1′−C13′ distance of 2.089 Å is in the usual range of known silver carbene complexes. The four silver−chloride bonds of Ag1−Cl1 = 2.368, Ag1−Cl1′ = 2.968, Ag1′−Cl1′ = 2.368, Ag1′−Cl1 = 2.968 Å and four angles of Cl1′−Ag1−Cl1 = 96.82, Cl1′−Ag1′−Cl1 = 96.82, Ag1−Cl1−Ag1′ = 83.18, Ag1−Cl1′−Ag1′ = 83.18° revealed that each Ag2Cl2 moiety forms a perfect rhombus with the sum of angles at the metal center being 360.00°. The Ag1−Ag1′ contacts of 3.570 Å, which is longer than the sum of van der Waals radii of two Ag(I) centers of 3.44 Å, is nonbonding. There is no argentophilic attraction observed in the packing block for the Ag···Ag distance of 9.502 Å.

elements.content: We then turned to the synthesis of 6a and 6b by transmetalation from the corresponding Ag−NHC complexes. We found it best to add [PdCl2(MeCN)2] directly to the Ag−NHC solutions after filtering off the unreacted silver oxide and insoluble residues. The addition of [PdCl2(MeCN)2] immediately gave the desired product and a white precipitate of silver chloride. The low yields of 6a and 6b are likely due to the fact that the reactions yield mixtures of monomers and oligomers that are separated during the purification process. The formation of 6a and 6b is confirmed by the signals for the carbene carbon atoms of 6a and 6b in the 13C NMR spectra appearing at 171.01 and 171.53 ppm, which are characteristic peaks for palladium carbene complexes.

elements.content: The pale yellow crystals of 6a suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by evaporating slowly its CH2Cl2/ethyl acetate/hexane solution at room temperature. The molecular structure of complex 6a is depicted in Figure . As expected, a 25-membered Pd−NHC metallacrown ether is formed by a bidentate chelate bis(carbene) ligand with a long flexible linkage and a Pd(II). The two benzene rings linked with ether oxygen atoms form a dihedral angle of 33.56°. The coordination geometry on the Pd is approximately square planar, with a C1−Pd−C1′ angle of 174.03° and a Cl1−Pd−Cl2 angle of 177.11°. The palladium−carbene distances (Pd1−C1 = 2.027 Å and Pd1−C1′ = 2.048 Å) are very similar to the Pd−Ccarbene bond distances found for complexes with two trans-positioned imidazolin-2-ylidene donor groups. The dihedral angle of the NHC rings is 8.62°.

elements.content: Compared with 6a, complex 6b·H2O also contains a 25-membered macrocyclic NHC metallacrown ether formed by a bidentate chelate bis(carbene) ligand with a long flexible linkage and a Pd(II) (Figure ). The coordination geometry on the Pd(II) is approximately square planar, with a C13−Pd−C13′ angle of 176.11°. This value is a little larger than 174.03° in 6a. The Cl1−Pd−Cl2 angle is 173.03°, which is smaller than 177.11° in 6a. The bond distances of Pd1−C13 = 2.029, Pd1−C13′ = 2.040, Pd1−Cl1 = 2.303, and Pd1−Cl2 = 2.316 Å are slightly different from 6a due to the variation of coordination environment. There are no H-bonds observed.

elements.content: The replacement of organic solvents by water in transition metal catalysis has received special attention because water is inexpensive, nontoxic, nonflammable, and environmentally sustainable. The palladium-catalyzed Suzuki−Miyaura reaction, which involves the coupling of aryl halides and arylboronic acids, has become one of the most powerful and convenient synthetic tools for the synthesis of biaryl compounds. Intensive research efforts are being directed to perform the Suzuki−Miyaura coupling either via aqueous biphasic catalysis or in neat water.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Studies

The replacement of organic solvents by water in transition metal catalysis has received special attention because water is inexpensive, nontoxic, nonflammable, and environmentally sustainable. The palladium-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura reaction, which involves the coupling of aryl halides and arylboronic acids, has become one of the most powerful and convenient synthetic tools for the synthesis of biaryl compounds. Intensive research efforts are being directed to perform the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling either via aqueous biphasic catalysis or in neat water.

elements.content: The Pd−NHC metallacrown ethers 6a and 6b are thermally stable and inert toward air and moisture in the solid state. They are then applied as potential catalysts for the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions under aerobic and aqueous conditions. We chose to examine the coupling of 4-bromoanisole with phenylboronic acid for the survey of the reaction parameters. As summarized in Table , the reaction conditions involving KOtBu appeared to be superior to the others. NaOAc, NaOH, NaOMe, NaOtBu, and KOH were less effective, and K3PO4 and Et3N gave moderate yields.

The above optimized conditions were used to examine a representative range of aryl bromides for the reaction. The results are summarized in Table . The coupling reaction of both activated and deactivated aryl bromides with arylboronic acids could be preformed smoothly even with a catalyst loading as low as 0.001 mol %. It is noteworthy that all cross-couplings listed in Table and Table were carried out under air, and no visible palladium black formation was observed during the catalytic process. Though various catalysts have been developed for the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions, very few examples can be used with a low catalyst loading of 0.001 mol % in neat water without the need of inert gas protection as the present Pd−NHC metallacrown ethers 6a and 6b can.

In summary, we have synthesized a novel type of bis(imidazolium) salts with a long polyether chain in four steps from simple, commercially available starting materials and characterized their Ag(I)−NHC complexes and Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ether complexes by X-ray structural analysis. The one-dimensional chain of Ag−carbene complex 5b is light and air stable in the solid state. Complexes 5 have been converted successfully to the desired form of Pd(II)−NHC metallacrown ethers 6, which have been shown to be highly effective in the Suzuki−Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection. Typically the use of 0.001−0.01 mol % of Pd catalyst gave the biaryl products in good to excellent yields with the TON up to 99 000. Further utilization of these Pd−NHC crown ether complexes is currently under investigation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized a novel type of bis(imidazolium) salts with a long polyether chain in four steps from simple, commercially available starting materials and characterized their Ag(I)-NHC complexes and Pd(II)-NHC metallacrown ether complexes by X-ray structural analysis. The one-dimensional chain of Ag-carbene complex 5b is light and air stable in the solid state. Complexes 5 have been converted successfully to the desired form of Pd(II)-NHC metallacrown ethers 6, which have been shown to be highly effective in the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of a variety of aryl bromides in neat water without the need of inert gas protection. Typically the use of 0.001-0.01 mol % of Pd catalyst gave the biaryl products in good to excellent yields with the TON up to 99000. Further utilization of these Pd-NHC crown ether complexes is currently under investigation.

Experimental Section

General Procedures

Unless otherwise noted, all manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. All solvents were dried according to standard procedures. 1,8-Bis(2-hydroxyphenoxy)-3,6-dioxaoctane (1), [PdCl2(MeCN)2] were prepared according to literature procedures. All other reagents are commercially available and were used without further purification.

elements.content: 1H (400 MHz, 600 MHz) and 13C (100 MHz, 150 MHz) NMR spectra were recorded using Bruker instruments. 1H and 13C chemical shifts are reported in ppm and calibrated to TMS on the basis of the solvent as an internal standard (7.27 ppm, CDCl3). All NMR spectra were acquired at room temperature. Melting points were determined with an XRC-1 melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. GC-MS were recorded on an Agilent Technologies 6890-5973N. Mass spectra were obtained by using Bruker Daltonics Data Analysis 3.2. Elemental analyses were performed on a Carlo Erba-1106 instrument.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for 5b, 6a, and 6b were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD-4 diffractometer at 294(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω/2θ scan mode. The structures were solved with direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In general, hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions, and their positions were refined by a riding model. Crystallographic data for 5b·2MeCN, 6a·CH2Cl2, and 6b·H2O are collected in the .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination and Refinement

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for 5b, 6a, and 6b were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD-4 diffractometer at 294(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω/2θ scan mode. The structures were solved with direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In general, hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions, and their positions were refined by a riding model. Crystallographic data for 5b⋅2MeCN, 6a⋅CH2Cl2, and 6b⋅H2O are collected in the .

In a typical run, aryl bromide (0.25 mmol), arylboronic acid (0.50 mmol), KOtBu (0.50 mmol), and Pd−NHC metallacrown ether complex 6b (10 μL, 0.0025 μmol) in dioxane were charged in a reaction tube equipped with a stirring bar. Water (1 mL) was then added to the mixture using a syringe. The reaction mixture was vigorously stirred at reflux in air. After 24 h the reaction was stopped. CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was added to the reaction mixture. The organic phase extracted from water was dried over Na2SO4. After evaporation of the solvent, the residue was purified by column chromatography to obtain the final products.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the Suzuki-Miyaura Cross-Coupling Reaction

In a typical run, aryl bromide (0.25 mmol), arylboronic acid (0.50 mmol), KOtBu (0.50 mmol), and Pd-NHC metallacrown ether complex 6b (10 μL, 0.0025 μmol) in dioxane were charged in a reaction tube equipped with a stirring bar. Water (1 mL) was then added to the mixture using a syringe. The reaction mixture was vigorously stirred at reflux in air. After 24 h the reaction was stopped. CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was added to the reaction mixture. The organic phase extracted from water was dried over Na2SO4. After evaporation of the solvent, the residue was purified by column chromatography to obtain the final products.

1,20-Dihydroxy-4,5,16,17-dibenzo-3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaoxaeicosane (2)

To a solution of dissolved 1,8-bis(2-hydroxyphenoxy)-3,6-dioxaoctane (1) (5.00 g, 15.0 mmol) and sodium hydroxide (1.55 g, 37.5 mmol) in butanol (30 mL) was added dropwise in 15 min 2-chloroethanol (2.50 mL, 37.5 mmol), and the mixture was refluxed for 24 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum. The resultant oil was dissolved in CH2Cl2, washed with aqueous sodium hydroxide and water, and dried over Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether, v/v = 3:1) to give a white solid. Yield: 3.5 g (56%).

1,20-Dichloro-4,5,16,17-dibenzo-3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaoxaeicosane (3)

To a solution of 2 (0.600 g, 1.4 mmol) in dry benzene (15 mL) were added thionyl chloride (0.52 mL, 7.0 mmol) and pyridine (0.46 mL, 7.0 mmol). The mixture was refluxed for 8 h and poured into water after cooling. The solution was extracted three times with ethyl acetate. The organic phase was dried over Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated and the residue was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether, v/v = 1/:1) to give an oil. Yield: 0.57 g (88%).

1,20-Di(1-mesitylimidazolium)-4,5,16,17-dibenzo-3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaoxaeicosane Dichloride (4a)

A solution of 3 (0.800 g, 1.7 mmol) and 1-mesitylimidazole (1.50 g, 7.0 mmol) in xylene (1 mL) was heated to 150 °C for 8 h. Then addition of ethyl acetate resulted in precipitation of a white powder, which was collected and washed with ethyl acetate (5 mL × 3) to afford the product. Yield: 1.37 g (97%).

1,20-Di[1-(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)imidazolium]-4,5,16,17-dibenzo-3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaoxaeicosane Dichloride (4b)

A solution of 3 (1.70 g, 3.7 mmol) and 1-(2,6-diisopropyl)phenylimidazole (1.85 g, 8.1 mmol) in xylene (1 mL) was heated to 150 °C for 8 h. After removal of the solvent, the residue was washed with ethyl acetate to give a yellow oil. Yield: 3.2 g (95%).

[Pd{1,20-Di(1-arylimidazolin-2-yliden-3-yl)-4,5,16,17-dibenzo-3,6,9,12,15,18-hexaoxaeicosane}Cl2] (6)

A mixture of bis(imidazolium) salts 4 (0.10 mmol) and silver(I) oxide (27.6 mg, 0.12 mmol) in 5 mL of CH2Cl2 was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The reaction mixture was filtered and washed with CH2Cl2 (5 mL × 2). The combined filtrate was reduced to 5 mL under vacuum. [PdCl2(MeCN)2] (25.8 mg, 0.10 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (3 mL) was added to the resulting solution and stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The reaction mixture was filtered and washed with CH2Cl2 (5 mL × 2). The combined solution was evaporated under reduced pressure to leave a raw product, which was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (CH2Cl2) to give a yellow solid.
